On the sensitivity of pose estimation neural networks: rotation parameterizations, Lipschitz constants, and provable bounds

Trevor Avant trevoravant@gmail.com    Kristi A. Morgansen morgansn@uw.edu Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195-2400, United States
Abstract

In this paper, we approach the task of determining sensitivity bounds for pose estimation neural networks. This task is particularly challenging as it requires characterizing the sensitivity of 3D rotations. We develop a sensitivity measure that describes the maximum rotational change in a network’s output with respect to a Euclidean change in its input. We show that this measure is a type of Lipschitz constant, and that it is bounded by the product of a network’s Euclidean Lipschitz constant and an intrinsic property of a rotation parameterization which we call the “distance ratio constant”. We derive the distance ratio constant for several rotation parameterizations, and then discuss why the structure of most of these parameterizations makes it difficult to construct a pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds. However, we show that sensitivity bounds can be computed for networks which parameterize rotation using unconstrained exponential coordinates. We then construct and train such a network and compute sensitivity bounds for it.

††thanks: This work was supported by ONR grant N00014-17-1-2623.††thanks: Code is available at https://github.com/uwaa-ndcl/pose_network_sensitivity

,

1 Introduction

In the past few years, deep neural networks have achieved remarkable success at the task of object pose estimation [1, 2, 3, 4]. However, a major downside of deep learning-based methods is that deep neural networks are not well-understood mathematically and lack provable performance guarantees. This lack of theoretical understanding is problematic as pose estimation networks are often intended to be applied to real-world applications which require safe and reliable operation. Therefore, it is necessary to develop better tools to analyze pose estimation networks in order to use them in the real world.

One significant disadvantage of deep neural networks is that they are often highly sensitive, and small changes in a network’s input can result in huge changes in its output [5]. One of the primary tools for analyzing neural network sensitivity is the Lipschitz constant, which measures the maximum distance between two outputs of a function with respect to the distance between the two corresponding inputs, taken over all admissible pairs of inputs. Although exact computation of a network’s Lipschitz constant is too formidable for all but very small networks [6], an upper bound can be computed instead. Other work has also considered estimating Lipschitz constants [7, 8, 9, 10], as well as specifically analyzing the sensitivity of classification networks (often with regard to adversarial examples) [11, 12, 13, 14].

While sensitivity analysis of general neural networks and of classification neural networks are active areas of research, to the best of our knowledge, the sensitivity of pose estimation neural networks has not yet been studied. This task is particularly challenging as sensitivity must be considered using a measure of rotational distance rather than a norm-based metric such as the Euclidean distance. As such, we measure network sensitivity as the maximum rotational distance between two outputs of a network with respect to the Euclidean distance between the two corresponding inputs. We show that this measure is a type of Lipschitz constant, and that it is bounded by the product of two values: the network’s Euclidean Lipschitz constant, and a measure we call the “distance ratio constant” which is the maximum ratio of the rotational and Euclidean distances between all pairs of rotation parameters.

Analyzing the sensitivity of a pose estimation network will depend on which specific rotation parameterization is used. A variety of rotation parameterizations have been used in the literature, with some examples shown in Figure 1. In this paper we consider five types of rotation parameterizations: exponential coordinates, unconstrained exponential coordinates, quaternions, unconstrained quaternions, and 2D projection parameterizations. We show how the structure of most of these parameterizations raise difficulties in constructing a pose estimation network with provable rotational sensitivity bounds. However, we demonstrate that such bounds can be determined for networks which parameterize rotation using unconstrained exponential coordinates. We then construct such a network and calculate rotational sensitivity bounds for it.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we discuss mathematical properties of 3D rotations and pose. In Section 3, we discuss Lipschitz constants, construct a Lipschitz constant that measures the sensitivity of a pose estimation neural network and derive a bound on it. We derive the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates and quaternions, respectively, in Sections 4 and 5. In Section 6, we summarize our findings from the previous sections and discuss their implications in creating a pose estimation neural network with provable bounds. We then go on to construct a pose estimation neural network which outputs rotation in the form of unconstrained exponential coordinates, and calculate sensitivity bounds for the network. Finally, we discuss areas of future work and provide concluding remarks in Section 7.

2 Pose and 3D rotations

In this section, we will provide background information on pose and 3D rotations of a rigid objects, and we will define a distance measure between 3D rotations.

2.1 Pose and 3D rotations

The pose of a rigid object is defined as its position and orientation. The set of all 3D positions and orientations is topologically characterized by SE(3), the “special Euclidean group” in three dimensional Euclidean space. Pose is often parameterized by treating position and rotation separately, in which case position can be described by a 3D vector, and rotation can be described by a rotation parameterization such as exponential coordinates or quaternions. In other representations of pose, such as 2D projected points, position and rotation are coupled.

The set of all rotations about the origin in three-dimensional Euclidean space is termed the special orthogonal group in three dimensions, SO(3). Each element of SO(3) can be described by an orthogonal 3×3333{\times}3 matrix with determinant equal to one:

SO(3)={𝐑∈ℝ3×3|𝐑T​𝐑=𝐈,det​(𝐑)=1}SO(3)conditional-set𝐑superscriptℝ33formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐑𝑇𝐑𝐈det𝐑1\textrm{SO(3)}=\{\mathbf{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3}~{}~{}|~{}~{}\mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I},~{}~{}\textrm{det}(\mathbf{R})=1\} (1)

where det​(⋅)det⋅\textrm{det}(\cdot) denotes the determinant operation, and 𝐈∈ℝ3×3𝐈superscriptℝ33\mathbf{I}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3} denotes the identity matrix.

There are many different parameterizations of the group of 3D rotations, including quaternions, exponential coordinates, and Euler angles. In this paper, we will use the symbol 𝒫⊆ℝm𝒫superscriptℝ𝑚\mathcal{P}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{m} to denote a set of rotation parameters, and the symbol 𝐩∈𝒫𝐩𝒫\mathbf{p}\in\mathcal{P} to denote a particular parameter in that set. The symbols 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} are generic in that they do not correspond to any specific parameterization, and they will be replaced with specific symbols when considering a specific rotation parameterization. For example, when considering quaternions, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} will be replaced with 𝒮3⊂ℝ4superscript𝒮3superscriptℝ4\mathcal{S}^{3}\subset\mathbb{R}^{4} (see (44)), and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} will be replaced with 𝐪∈ℝ4𝐪superscriptℝ4\mathbf{q}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}.

2.2 Rotational distance

We now consider the task of quantifying the “distance” between two 3D rotations. As the set of 3D rotations is structured as a Riemannian manifold, Euclidean distance cannot be used to properly measure distance for rotations. A proper measure of rotational distance is the angle of direct rotation between two 3D rotations. This measure provides a consistent measure of rotational distance, can be applied to any rotation parameterization, and is intuitive as it corresponds to an angle of rotation.

Definition 1.

The rotational distance between two 3D rotations is the angle of direct rotation between the two rotations using an axis-angle representation. Letting 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} denote a set of rotation parameters, we denote the rotational distance function as dist:𝒫×𝒫→[0,π]:dist→𝒫𝒫0𝜋\mathrm{dist}:\mathcal{P}\times\mathcal{P}\rightarrow[0,\pi].

The function dist​(⋅,⋅)dist⋅⋅\mathrm{dist}(\cdot,\cdot) is overloaded notation as its explicit expression will depend on which rotation parameterization is being considering. For example, the rotational distance between two rotation matrices 𝐑1,𝐑2∈ℝ3×3subscript𝐑1subscript𝐑2superscriptℝ33\mathbf{R}_{1},\mathbf{R}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3} is given by the following equation:

dist​(𝐑1,𝐑2)distsubscript𝐑1subscript𝐑2\displaystyle\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{R}_{1},\mathbf{R}_{2}) =cos−1⁡(12​(tr​(𝐑1​𝐑2T)−1))absentsuperscript112trsubscript𝐑1superscriptsubscript𝐑2𝑇1\displaystyle=\cos^{-1}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\textrm{tr}(\mathbf{R}_{1}\mathbf{R}_{2}^{T})-1)\right) (2)

where tr​(⋅)tr⋅\textrm{tr}(\cdot) denotes the trace operation. Later in the paper, we consider the distance between two pairs of exponential coordinates, dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}), in (16), and the distance between two quaternions, dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}), in (45).

3 Lipschitz constants and measures of sensitivity for pose estimation neural networks

In this section, we will consider measuring the sensitivity of a pose estimation network, which can be thought of as a mathematical function which inputs a camera image (or similar structure) and outputs a rotation parameterization. Our analysis requires several tools which we will now define: metrics, pseudometrics, and Lipschitz constants.

3.1 Lipschitz constants

We start by defining metrics and pseudometrics [16, Ch. 4], which will be used to define Lipschitz constants.

Definition 2.

A function d:𝒳×𝒳→[0,∞):𝑑→𝒳𝒳0d:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\to[0,\infty) is a metric on set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} if it satisfies properties (a), (b), (c), and (d) below, for all x,y,z∈𝒳𝑥𝑦𝑧𝒳x,y,z\in\mathcal{X}. Additionally, a function d:𝒳×𝒳→[0,∞):𝑑→𝒳𝒳0d:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\to[0,\infty) is a pseudometric on set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} if it only satisfies properties (a), (b), and (c), for all x,y,z∈𝒳𝑥𝑦𝑧𝒳x,y,z\in\mathcal{X}.

  1. (a)

    d​(x,y)=d​(y,x)𝑑𝑥𝑦𝑑𝑦𝑥d(x,y)=d(y,x)

  2. (b)

    d​(x,y)≤d​(x,z)+d​(z,y)𝑑𝑥𝑦𝑑𝑥𝑧𝑑𝑧𝑦d(x,y)\leq d(x,z)+d(z,y)

  3. (c)

    d​(x,y)=0⇐x=y𝑑𝑥𝑦0⇐𝑥𝑦d(x,y)=0~{}~{}~{}\Leftarrow~{}~{}~{}x=y

  4. (d)

    d​(x,y)=0⇒x=y𝑑𝑥𝑦0⇒𝑥𝑦d(x,y)=0~{}~{}~{}\Rightarrow~{}~{}~{}x=y

Lipschitz constants are a tool to quantify the sensitivity of mathematical functions, and are one of the main tools used to analyze the sensitivity of neural networks. Given a function, 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}, the Lipschitz constant describes the maximum amount the output of the function can change with respect to changes in the input [17, Ch. 9]. Lipschitz constants are useful due to their applicability to a wide array of functions, including vector-valued, nonlinear, and non-differentiable functions.

Definition 3.

Consider a function 𝐟:𝒳→𝒴:𝐟→𝒳𝒴\mathbf{f}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}, and metrics d𝒳:𝒳×𝒳→[0,∞):subscript𝑑𝒳→𝒳𝒳0d_{\mathcal{X}}:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\rightarrow[0,\infty) and d𝒴:𝒴×𝒴→[0,∞):subscript𝑑𝒴→𝒴𝒴0d_{\mathcal{Y}}:\mathcal{Y}\times\mathcal{Y}\rightarrow[0,\infty). The Lipschitz constant, L∈ℝ𝐿ℝL\in\mathbb{R}, of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} with respect to d𝒳subscript𝑑𝒳d_{\mathcal{X}} and d𝒴subscript𝑑𝒴d_{\mathcal{Y}} is the minimal L≥0𝐿0L\geq 0 such that

d𝒴​(𝐟​(𝐱1),𝐟​(𝐱2))≤L​d𝒳​(𝐱1,𝐱2),∀𝐱1,𝐱2∈𝒳.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝒴𝐟subscript𝐱1𝐟subscript𝐱2𝐿subscript𝑑𝒳subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2for-allsubscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2𝒳d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1}),\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2}))\leq Ld_{\mathcal{X}}(\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2}),~{}~{}~{}~{}\forall\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2}\in\mathcal{X}. (3)

Note that some authors define any L𝐿L that satisfies the inequality above as “a Lipschitz constant”, but we will define “the Lipschitz constant” as the minimal L𝐿L for which this inequality holds, and we refer to any larger value as an upper bound. We can solve for L𝐿L in (3) as

L=sup𝐱1,𝐱2∈𝒳𝐱1≠𝐱2d𝒴​(𝐟​(𝐱1),𝐟​(𝐱2))d𝒳​(𝐱1,𝐱2).𝐿subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2𝒳subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2subscript𝑑𝒴𝐟subscript𝐱1𝐟subscript𝐱2subscript𝑑𝒳subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2L=\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2}\in\mathcal{X}\\ \mathbf{x}_{1}\neq\mathbf{x}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1}),\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2}))}{d_{\mathcal{X}}(\mathbf{x}_{1},\mathbf{x}_{2})}. (4)

Note that excluding points such that 𝐱1=𝐱2subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2\mathbf{x}_{1}{=}\mathbf{x}_{2} does not affect the supremization above since these points satisfy (3) for any L𝐿L.

3.2 Euclidean Lipschitz constants

In this paper, we are interested in the case in which the function 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is a neural network that maps an image or other type of input to a rotation parameter. We can write this function as 𝐟:ℝn→𝒫:𝐟→superscriptℝ𝑛𝒫\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathcal{P}. Lipschitz constants are typically applied to neural networks using the metrics induced by the 1-, 2-, and ∞\infty-norms for d𝒳subscript𝑑𝒳d_{\mathcal{X}} and d𝒴subscript𝑑𝒴d_{\mathcal{Y}}. We now present the Lipschitz constant in which both metrics are defined as the Euclidean distance.

Definition 4.

Consider a function 𝐟:ℝn→𝒫:𝐟→superscriptℝ𝑛𝒫\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{P} which outputs a rotation parameter. The Euclidean Lipschitz constant, Lesubscript𝐿𝑒L_{e}, of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is the Lipschitz constant of the function using the Euclidean distance as the metric on both the input and output sets:

Le≔sup𝐱1≠𝐱2∥𝐟​(𝐱2)−𝐟​(𝐱1)∥∥𝐱2−𝐱1∥.≔subscript𝐿𝑒subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2delimited-∥∥𝐟subscript𝐱2𝐟subscript𝐱1delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱2subscript𝐱1L_{e}\coloneqq\sup_{\mathbf{x}_{1}\neq\mathbf{x}_{2}}\frac{\lVert\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2})-\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1})\rVert}{\lVert\mathbf{x}_{2}-\mathbf{x}_{1}\rVert}. (5)

3.3 Rotational Lipschitz constants

Considering a neural network, 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}, that maps an image to a rotation parameter, the Euclidean Lipschitz constant does not provide a meaningful measure of sensitivity due to the fact that the Euclidean distance between two rotation parameters is not a meaningful measure of rotational distance. So, to properly measure the sensitivity of these functions, we will create a Lipschitz constant that measures the distance between inputs using the Euclidean distance, and the distance between outputs using the rotational distance from Definition 1. We present this measure in the following definition.

Definition 5.

Consider a function 𝐟:ℝn→𝒫:𝐟→superscriptℝ𝑛𝒫\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{P} that outputs a rotation parameter. The rotational Lipschitz constant, Lrsubscript𝐿𝑟L_{r}, of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is the Lipschitz constant of the function using the Euclidean distance as the metric on the input set, and the rotational distance as the metric on the output set:

Lr≔sup𝐱1≠𝐱2dist​(𝐟​(𝐱1),𝐟​(𝐱2))∥𝐱2−𝐱1∥.≔subscript𝐿𝑟subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2dist𝐟subscript𝐱1𝐟subscript𝐱2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱2subscript𝐱1L_{r}\coloneqq\sup_{\mathbf{x}_{1}\neq\mathbf{x}_{2}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1}),\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2}))}{\lVert\mathbf{x}_{2}-\mathbf{x}_{1}\rVert}. (6)

We now note that the rotational distance function dist​(⋅,⋅)dist⋅⋅\mathrm{dist}(\cdot,\cdot) from Definition 1 is a pseudometric and not a metric, which is due to the fact for some rotation parameterizations, dist​(𝐩1,𝐩2)distsubscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2}) may equal zero for some parameters 𝐩1≠𝐩2subscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2\mathbf{p}_{1}{\neq}\mathbf{p}_{2}. As a result, the rotational Lipschitz constant Lrsubscript𝐿𝑟L_{r} is not a true Lipschitz constant as described in Definition 3. However, this discrepancy is minor and does not have any negative effects on using the rotational Lipschitz constant to measure the sensitivity of a neural network.

As with Euclidean Lipschitz constants, it is too difficult to exactly calculate the rotational Lipschitz constant of complex functions such as neural networks, so instead we will derive an upper bound. This bound will require defining the following measure which relates the Euclidean and rotational distances between pairs of rotation parameters.

Definition 6.

Consider a rotation parameterization with set of parameters, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. The distance ratio constant, μ𝜇\mu, of the parameterization is the maximum ratio of the rotational distance to the Euclidean distance over all pairs of parameters:

μ≔sup𝐩1,𝐩2∈𝒫𝐩1≠𝐩2dist​(𝐩1,𝐩2)∥𝐩2−𝐩1∥.≔𝜇subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2𝒫subscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2distsubscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐩2subscript𝐩1\mu\coloneqq\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2}\in\mathcal{P}\\ \mathbf{p}_{1}\neq\mathbf{p}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{p}_{2}-\mathbf{p}_{1}\rVert}. (7)

Note this definition is equivalent to applying the rotational Lipschitz constant from Definition 5 to the identity map 𝐟​(𝐩)=𝐩𝐟𝐩𝐩\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{p})=\mathbf{p}.

3.4 Bounds on the rotational Lipschitz constant

Using Lesubscript𝐿𝑒L_{e} and μ𝜇\mu, we can now derive a bound on a rotational Lipschitz constant Lrsubscript𝐿𝑟L_{r}.

Let Lrsubscript𝐿𝑟L_{r} denote the rotational Lipschitz constant of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}, let Lesubscript𝐿𝑒L_{e} denote the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}, and let μ𝜇\mu denote the distance ratio constant of the rotation parameterization. The following equation holds:

Theorem 7 can be used in practice to determine rotational bounds on the output of a function based on Euclidean bounds on the input. This result is summarized in the following corollary.

Corollary 8.

Consider a function 𝐟:ℝn→𝒫:𝐟→superscriptℝ𝑛𝒫\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{P} that outputs a rotation parameter. Note that this bound will only be useful if the right hand side of (12) is less than the maximum possible rotational distance of π𝜋\pi.

3.5 Application to pose estimation neural networks

The function, 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}, that we have considered in this section will correspond to a feedforward pose estimation neural network. In order to apply the results from this section to such a network, there are several considerations we must make.

First, note that for networks which take RGB images as their inputs, the input, 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, will be a three-dimensional array. It is mathematically equivalent to consider such inputs to be vectors in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}. Also note that we have considered a function, 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}, which outputs rotation parameters, but a pose estimation neural network will output pose, which consists of both position and rotation. However, pose is often represented as a concatenation of position and rotation, so in these cases we can split a network into position and rotation sub-networks, and consider each sub-network separately. Finally, as we noted before, the exact Euclidean Lipschitz constant, Lesubscript𝐿𝑒L_{e}, is intractable to compute for all but very small toy networks, but an upper bound can be computed instead by taking the product of the individual bounds of the layers of the network.

In summary, we would like to compute a bound on the rotational Lipschitz constant from Theorem 7 for a pose estimation neural network. This bound is a function of two values: the Euclidean Lipschitz constant, Lesubscript𝐿𝑒L_{e}, and the distance ratio constant, μ𝜇\mu. While we know how to compute an upper bound on Lesubscript𝐿𝑒L_{e}, we are not aware of any work in which μ𝜇\mu is derived for any rotation parameterization. Accordingly, we will devote the next two sections of the paper to the derivation of μ𝜇\mu for two types of rotation parameterizations: exponential coordinates and quaternions.

Note that a common pose parameterization used in pose estimation networks is 2D projected points, in which pose is parameterized by a set of 2D points which represent 3D points on the object which have been projected into the image plane [1, 2, 4]. Unfortunately, for these types of parameterizations, the mapping between parameters and pose relies on Perspective-n-Point (PnP) algorithms, which often are solved via nonlinear optimization and also often rely on additional algorithms such as Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC). As a result, deriving closed-form sensitivity bounds for these parameterizations is intractable.

4 Exponential coordinates

In this section, we will derive the distance ratio constant from Definition 6 for exponential coordinates and unconstrained exponential coordinates.

4.1 Rotation parameterization

The first rotation parameterization we will consider is exponential coordinates. Although not commonly used in pose estimation neural networks, exponential coordinates are a fundamental and intuitive description of rotation used frequently in robotics applications. Additionally, as we will show later on, exponential coordinates have several properties which make them advantageous for developing pose estimation networks with provable sensitivity bounds.

Any 3D rotation can be described by a rotation of angle θ∈ℝ𝜃ℝ\theta\in\mathbb{R} about a unit-length axis 𝐞∈ℝ3𝐞superscriptℝ3\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}. Exponential coordinates, which we will denote as 𝐬∈ℝ3𝐬superscriptℝ3\mathbf{s}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}, are simply the axis multiplied by the angle: 𝐬=θ​𝐞∈ℝ3𝐬𝜃𝐞superscriptℝ3\mathbf{s}=\theta\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} [18, Ch. 3]. The term “exponential” comes from the fact that SO(3) is a Lie group, and exponential coordinates are a description of the Lie algebra of the Lie group, which can be mapped back to the group using the exponential map.

In general, exponential coordinates can be defined using any angle θ∈[0,∞)𝜃0\theta\in[0,\infty). We refer to the set of exponential coordinates defined with θ∈[0,∞)𝜃0\theta\in[0,\infty) as “unconstrained” exponential coordinates. However, exponential coordinates are typically defined with θ∈[0,π]𝜃0𝜋\theta\in[0,\pi], which is the minimum set of angles that can describe all 3D rotations. This set of exponential coordinates corresponds to the three-dimensional ball of radius π𝜋\pi, which we denote as ℬπsubscriptℬ𝜋\mathcal{B}_{\pi}:

ℬπ={𝐱∈ℝ3|∥𝐱∥≤π}.subscriptℬ𝜋conditional-set𝐱superscriptℝ3delimited-∥∥𝐱𝜋\displaystyle\mathcal{B}_{\pi}=\{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}~{}~{}|~{}~{}\lVert\mathbf{x}\rVert\leq\pi\}. (14)

There is a 1-to-1 mapping between points inside ℬπsubscriptℬ𝜋\mathcal{B}_{\pi} and 3D rotations, and a 2-to-1 mapping between points on the surface ℬπsubscriptℬ𝜋\mathcal{B}_{\pi} to 3D rotations. More specifically, antipodal points on the surface of the ball correspond to the same rotation (i.e., π​𝐞𝜋𝐞\pi\mathbf{e} and −π​𝐞𝜋𝐞-\pi\mathbf{e} correspond to the same rotation) [18, Ch. 3]. Note that while we could reduce the set ℬπsubscriptℬ𝜋\mathcal{B}_{\pi} so that it is a 1-to-1 mapping, it would not change the results in this section.

We now consider how exponential coordinates can be composed. Let 𝐬1=θ1​𝐞1subscript𝐬1subscript𝜃1subscript𝐞1\mathbf{s}_{1}=\theta_{1}\mathbf{e}_{1} and 𝐬2=θ2​𝐞2subscript𝐬2subscript𝜃2subscript𝐞2\mathbf{s}_{2}=\theta_{2}\mathbf{e}_{2} denote two sets of exponential coordinates, and let 𝐬3=θ3​𝐞3subscript𝐬3subscript𝜃3subscript𝐞3\mathbf{s}_{3}=\theta_{3}\mathbf{e}_{3} denote the coordinates of the composite rotation of 𝐬1subscript𝐬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and 𝐬2subscript𝐬2\mathbf{s}_{2}. The angle θ3subscript𝜃3\theta_{3} can be determined using the following formula [19]:

cos⁡θ32=cos⁡θ12​cos⁡θ22−𝐞1⋅𝐞2​sin⁡θ12​sin⁡θ22.subscript𝜃32subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22\displaystyle\cos\tfrac{\theta_{3}}{2}=\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}-\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}. (15)

4.2 Rotational distance

Using (15), we can derive the rotational distance between two pairs of exponential coordinates.

Proposition 9.

The rotational distance between two pairs of exponential coordinates, 𝐬1=θ1​𝐞1subscript𝐬1subscript𝜃1subscript𝐞1\mathbf{s}_{1}=\theta_{1}\mathbf{e}_{1} and 𝐬2=θ2​𝐞2subscript𝐬2subscript𝜃2subscript𝐞2\mathbf{s}_{2}=\theta_{2}\mathbf{e}_{2}, is given by the following equation:

dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)=2​cos−1⁡(|cos⁡θ12​cos⁡θ22+𝐞1⋅𝐞2​sin⁡θ12​sin⁡θ22|).missing-subexpressiondistsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2missing-subexpressionabsent2superscript1subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22\displaystyle\begin{aligned} &\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2})\\ &\hskip 8.53581pt=2\cos^{-1}(\lvert\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}+\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\rvert).\end{aligned} (16)
{pf}

The rotational distance can be determined by finding the angle corresponding to the composite axis-angle rotation between the first rotation 𝐬1subscript𝐬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and the inverse of the second rotation. The inverse of the second rotation is found by simply negating the angle of rotation θ2subscript𝜃2\theta_{2}, and is therefore described by the exponential coordinates −𝐬2=−θ2​𝐞2subscript𝐬2subscript𝜃2subscript𝐞2-\mathbf{s}_{2}=-\theta_{2}\mathbf{e}_{2}. To find the angle of the composite rotation, we can use (15):

cos⁡θ32subscript𝜃32\displaystyle\cos\tfrac{\theta_{3}}{2} =cos⁡θ12​cos⁡−θ22−𝐞1⋅𝐞2​sin⁡θ12​sin⁡−θ22absentsubscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22\displaystyle=\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{-\theta_{2}}{2}-\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{-\theta_{2}}{2} (17)
=cos⁡θ12​cos⁡θ22+𝐞1⋅𝐞2​sin⁡θ12​sin⁡θ22absentsubscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22\displaystyle=\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}+\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2} (18)

where we have used the trigonometric identities sin⁡(−x)=−sin⁡(x)𝑥𝑥\sin(-x)=-\sin(x) and cos⁡(−x)=cos⁡(x)𝑥𝑥\cos(-x)=\cos(x). Next, for convenience, we define

a≔cos⁡θ12​cos⁡θ22+𝐞1⋅𝐞2​sin⁡θ12​sin⁡θ22≔𝑎subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22a\coloneqq\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}+\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2} (19)

and note that a∈[−1,1]𝑎11a\in[-1,1]. Solving for θ3subscript𝜃3\theta_{3} in (18) and using (19), we have

θ3=2​cos−1⁡(a).subscript𝜃32superscript1𝑎\displaystyle\theta_{3}=2\cos^{-1}(a). (20)

Arccosine will map to the interval [0,π]0𝜋[0,\pi], so θ3subscript𝜃3\theta_{3} in (20) will be mapped to the interval [0,2​π]02𝜋[0,2\pi]. However, we would like to express θ3subscript𝜃3\theta_{3} as the rotational distance from zero, which is on the interval [0,π]0𝜋[0,\pi]. So, we can write

dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)={θ3,θ3∈[0,π]2​π−θ3,θ3∈[π,2​π].distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2casessubscript𝜃3subscript𝜃30𝜋2𝜋subscript𝜃3subscript𝜃3𝜋2𝜋\displaystyle\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2})=\begin{cases}\theta_{3},&\theta_{3}\in[0,\pi]\\ 2\pi-\theta_{3},&\theta_{3}\in[\pi,2\pi].\end{cases} (21)

Because θ3subscript𝜃3\theta_{3} will be greater than π𝜋\pi when the argument to the arccosine (i.e., a𝑎a) is negative, using (20) we can rewrite (21) as

dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2\displaystyle\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}) ={2​cos−1⁡(a),a∈[0,1]2​π−2​cos−1⁡(a),a∈[−1,0].absentcases2superscript1𝑎𝑎012𝜋2superscript1𝑎𝑎10\displaystyle=\begin{cases}2\cos^{-1}(a),&a\in[0,1]\\ 2\pi-2\cos^{-1}(a),&a\in[-1,0].\end{cases} (22)

Now note that we can write cos−1⁡(|x|)superscript1𝑥\cos^{-1}(\lvert x\rvert) in the following way, based on the sign of the argument:

cos−1⁡(|x|)={π−cos−1⁡(x),x∈[−1,0]cos−1⁡(x),x∈[0,1].superscript1𝑥cases𝜋superscript1𝑥𝑥10superscript1𝑥𝑥01\cos^{-1}(\lvert x\rvert)=\begin{cases}\pi-\cos^{-1}(x),&x\in[-1,0]\\ \cos^{-1}(x),&x\in[0,1].\end{cases} (23)

Using (23) we can write (22) as (16), which completes the proof. □□\square

4.3 Planar analysis

To determine the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates from Definition 6, we would need to optimize over all possible pairs of exponential coordinates, where each pair consists of the six degrees of freedom in 𝐬1subscript𝐬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and 𝐬2subscript𝐬2\mathbf{s}_{2}, and the two constraints ∥𝐬1∥≤πdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐬1𝜋\lVert\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert\leq\pi and ∥𝐬2∥≤πdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2𝜋\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}\rVert\leq\pi. The number of dimensions and constraints in this analysis is challenging, but we can analyze this problem in the plane defined by 𝐬1subscript𝐬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and 𝐬2subscript𝐬2\mathbf{s}_{2}, which reduces the number of variables and simplifies the analysis.

Lemma 10.

Consider the exponential coordinates 𝐬1=θ1​𝐞1subscript𝐬1subscript𝜃1subscript𝐞1\mathbf{s}_{1}=\theta_{1}\mathbf{e}_{1} and 𝐬2=θ2​𝐞2subscript𝐬2subscript𝜃2subscript𝐞2\mathbf{s}_{2}=\theta_{2}\mathbf{e}_{2} where θ1,θ2∈[0,∞)subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃20\theta_{1},\theta_{2}\in[0,\infty). Define the variable t𝑡t:

t≔12​(1−𝐞1⋅𝐞2),t∈[0,1].formulae-sequence≔𝑡121⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2𝑡01\displaystyle t\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{2}(1-\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}),~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}t\in[0,1]. (24)

The Euclidean and rotational distances between 𝐬1subscript𝐬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and 𝐬2subscript𝐬2\mathbf{s}_{2} are:

∥𝐬2−𝐬1∥=(θ1−θ2)2+4​θ1​θ2​tdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2subscript𝐬1superscriptsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃224subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2𝑡\displaystyle\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert=\sqrt{(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})^{2}+4\theta_{1}\theta_{2}t} (25)
dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)=2​cos−1⁡(|t​cos⁡(θ12+θ22)+(1−t)​cos⁡(θ12−θ22)|).distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬22superscript1𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃221𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22\displaystyle\begin{split}&\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2})\\ &\hskip 8.53581pt=2\cos^{-1}(|t\cos(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}{+}\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2})+(1{-}t)\cos(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}{-}\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2})|).\end{split} (26)
{pf}

We note that any two exponential coordinates 𝐬1subscript𝐬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and 𝐬2subscript𝐬2\mathbf{s}_{2} lie in a plane, and hence we can analyze their relationship in that plane. A diagram is shown in Fig. 2.

First, note the following equation which relates the dot product and angle between two vectors:

cos⁡ϕ=𝐞1⋅𝐞2.italic-ϕ⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2\displaystyle\cos\phi=\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}. (27)

To show (25), we can use the law of cosines to express the Euclidean distance between two points (see Fig. 2):

∥𝐬2−𝐬1∥=θ12+θ22−2​θ1​θ2​cos⁡ϕ.delimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2subscript𝐬1superscriptsubscript𝜃12superscriptsubscript𝜃222subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2italic-ϕ\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert=\sqrt{\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}-2\theta_{1}\theta_{2}\cos\phi}. (28)

Using (27) and (24), the equation above can be manipulated to yield (25).

To show (LABEL:eq:rotational_distance_exp_coords_2d), we can substitute (27) into (16), apply the product-to-sum formula, and then manipulate the resulting equation algebraically which yields (LABEL:eq:rotational_distance_exp_coords_2d). □□\square

4.4 Distance ratio constants

We now approach the problem of analytically determining the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates. We will start by deriving the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates with angles on the interval [0,2​π]02𝜋[0,2\pi]. We will then use this result to determine the distance ratio constant for unconstrained exponential coordinates and exponential coordinates in Theorems 12 and 13.

Lemma 11.

The distance ratio constant, μ𝜇\mu, for exponential coordinates 𝐬1=θ1​𝐞1subscript𝐬1subscript𝜃1subscript𝐞1\mathbf{s}_{1}=\theta_{1}\mathbf{e}_{1} and 𝐬2=θ2​𝐞2subscript𝐬2subscript𝜃2subscript𝐞2\mathbf{s}_{2}=\theta_{2}\mathbf{e}_{2} for which θ1,θ2∈[0,2​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃202𝜋\theta_{1},\theta_{2}\in[0,2\pi] is:

μ=sup𝐬1,𝐬2∈ℬ2​π𝐬1≠𝐬2dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)∥𝐬2−𝐬1∥=1.𝜇subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2subscriptℬ2𝜋subscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2subscript𝐬11\displaystyle\mu=\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}\in\mathcal{B}_{2\pi}\\ \mathbf{s}_{1}\neq\mathbf{s}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert}=1. {pf}

Recall from Lemma 10 that the Euclidean and rotational distances between any pair of exponential coordinates can be written as (25) and (LABEL:eq:rotational_distance_exp_coords_2d) where t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]. From these equations, we can write the argument of the distance ratio constant as

dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)∥𝐬2−𝐬1∥=2​cos−1⁡(|t​cos⁡(θ12+θ22)+(1−t)​cos⁡(θ12−θ22)|)(θ1−θ2)2+4​θ1​θ2​t.missing-subexpressiondistsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2subscript𝐬1missing-subexpressionabsent2superscript1𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃221𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22superscriptsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃224subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2𝑡\displaystyle\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert}\\ &\hskip 17.07164pt=\frac{2\cos^{-1}\left(\lvert t\cos(\frac{\theta_{1}}{2}+\frac{\theta_{2}}{2})+(1-t)\cos(\frac{\theta_{1}}{2}-\frac{\theta_{2}}{2})\rvert\right)}{\sqrt{(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})^{2}+4\theta_{1}\theta_{2}t}}.\end{aligned} (30)

Using convexity, we will first show that the equation above is less than or equal to one, for the case in which θ1,θ2∈[0,2​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃202𝜋\theta_{1},\theta_{2}\in[0,2\pi] and θ1+θ2∈[0,2​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃202𝜋\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\in[0,2\pi].

t​cos⁡(x1)+(1−t)​cos⁡(x2)≥cos⁡(t​x1+(1−t)​x2).𝑡subscript𝑥11𝑡subscript𝑥2𝑡subscript𝑥11𝑡subscript𝑥2\displaystyle t\cos(\sqrt{x_{1}})+(1-t)\cos(\sqrt{x_{2}})\geq\cos(\sqrt{tx_{1}+(1-t)x_{2}}). (31)

Substituting these values into (31) and manipulating the equation algebraically yields

t​cos⁡(θ12+θ22)+(1−t)​cos⁡(θ12−θ22)≥cos⁡(12​(θ1−θ2)2+4​θ1​θ2​t)missing-subexpression𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃221𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22missing-subexpressionabsent12superscriptsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃224subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2𝑡\displaystyle\begin{aligned} &t\cos(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}+\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2})+(1-t)\cos(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}-\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2})\\ &\hskip 73.97716pt\geq\cos(\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})^{2}+4\theta_{1}\theta_{2}t})\end{aligned} (32)

where we have used the fact that cos⁡(x2)=cos⁡(|x|)=cos⁡(x)superscript𝑥2𝑥𝑥\cos(\sqrt{x^{2}})=\cos(\lvert x\rvert)=\cos(x).

Next, we will apply the arccosine function to both sides of (32). Note that the argument of the cosine function on the RHS of (32) is on the interval [0,π]0𝜋[0,\pi] and therefore applying the arccosine function to the RHS will return the original argument of the cosine function. Also, note that the LHS is on the interval [−1,1]11[-1,1] because it is a convex combination of cosine functions. Since arccosine is a decreasing function, we can apply it to both sides of (32) and flip the inequality:

cos−1⁡(t​cos⁡(θ12+θ22)+(1−t)​cos⁡(θ12−θ22))≤12​(θ1−θ2)2+4​θ1​θ2​t.missing-subexpressionsuperscript1𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃221𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22missing-subexpressionabsent12superscriptsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃224subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2𝑡\displaystyle\begin{aligned} &\cos^{-1}\left(t\cos(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}+\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2})+(1-t)\cos(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}-\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2})\right)\\ &\hskip 93.89409pt\leq\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})^{2}+4\theta_{1}\theta_{2}t}.\end{aligned} (33)

2​cos−1⁡(|t​cos⁡(θ12+θ22)+(1−t)​cos⁡(θ12−θ22)|)≤(θ1−θ2)2+4​θ1​θ2​t.missing-subexpression2superscript1𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃221𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃224subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2𝑡\displaystyle\begin{aligned} &2\cos^{-1}\left(\lvert t\cos\left(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}+\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\right)+(1-t)\cos\left(\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}-\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\right)\rvert\right)\\ &\hskip 128.0374pt\leq\sqrt{(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})^{2}+4\theta_{1}\theta_{2}t}.\end{aligned} (34)

Dividing by the RHS yields

2​cos−1⁡(|t​cos⁡(θ12+θ22)+(1−t)​cos⁡(θ12−θ22)|)(θ1−θ2)2+4​θ1​θ2​t≤1.missing-subexpression2superscript1𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃221𝑡subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22superscriptsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃224subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2𝑡1\displaystyle\begin{aligned} &\frac{2\cos^{-1}\left(\lvert t\cos(\frac{\theta_{1}}{2}+\frac{\theta_{2}}{2})+(1-t)\cos(\frac{\theta_{1}}{2}-\frac{\theta_{2}}{2})\rvert\right)}{\sqrt{(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})^{2}+4\theta_{1}\theta_{2}t}}\leq 1.\end{aligned} (35)

We can see that the expression on the LHS is the same as the RHS of (30). So, we have shown that the distance ratio constant is less than or equal to one for cases in which θ1,θ2∈[0,2​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃202𝜋\theta_{1},\theta_{2}\in[0,2\pi] and θ1+θ2∈[0,2​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃202𝜋\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\in[0,2\pi]. We can complete the Lemma by showing that the distance ratio constant is less than or equal to one in cases for which θ1,θ2∈[0,2​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃202𝜋\theta_{1},\theta_{2}\in[0,2\pi] and θ1+θ2∈[2​π,4​π]subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃22𝜋4𝜋\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\in[2\pi,4\pi].

Next, we can use Lemma 11 to derive the distance ratio constant for unconstrained exponential coordinates. Note that the set of unconstrained exponential coordinates is all of ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}.

Finally, we show that the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates with angles θ∈[0,π]𝜃0𝜋\theta\in[0,\pi] also equals one.

Theorem 13.

The distance ratio constant, μ𝜇\mu, of exponential coordinates with angles on the interval [0,π]0𝜋[0,\pi] is:

μ=sup𝐬1,𝐬2∈ℬπ𝐬1≠𝐬2dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)∥𝐬2−𝐬1∥=1.𝜇subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2subscriptℬ𝜋subscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2subscript𝐬11\displaystyle\mu=\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}\in\mathcal{B}_{\pi}\\ \mathbf{s}_{1}\neq\mathbf{s}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert}=1. (42)
{pf}

Lemma 11 states that the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates with angles θ∈[0,2​π]𝜃02𝜋\theta\in[0,2\pi] is one. Exponential coordinates with angles θ∈[0,π]𝜃0𝜋\theta\in[0,\pi] are a subset of those exponential coordinates, and therefore the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates with angles θ∈[0,π]𝜃0𝜋\theta\in[0,\pi] is upper bounded by one. Furthermore, this upper bound is achieved in a few ways, one of which being when θ1∈(0,π]subscript𝜃10𝜋\theta_{1}\in(0,\pi] and θ2=0subscript𝜃20\theta_{2}=0, in which case both dist​(𝐬1,𝐬2)distsubscript𝐬1subscript𝐬2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}) and ∥𝐬2−𝐬1∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐬2subscript𝐬1\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert equal θ1subscript𝜃1\theta_{1}. □□\square

5 Quaternions

In this section, we will derive the distance ratio constant from Definition 6 for quaternions and unconstrained quaternions.

5.1 Rotation parameterization

Quaternions are a common representation of rotation which can be derived from an axis-angle representation. Considering an angle, θ∈ℝ𝜃ℝ\theta\in\mathbb{R}, and unit-length axis, 𝐞∈ℝ3𝐞superscriptℝ3\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}, a quaternion can be written as [18, App. A]

𝐪=[cos⁡θ2𝐞​sin⁡θ2]∈ℝ4.𝐪matrix𝜃2𝐞𝜃2superscriptℝ4\mathbf{q}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\tfrac{\theta}{2}\\ \mathbf{e}\sin\tfrac{\theta}{2}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}. (43)

The set of all possible quaternions corresponds to all 4D vectors with unit norm, which is equivalent to all points on the 3-sphere, 𝒮3⊂ℝ4superscript𝒮3superscriptℝ4\mathcal{S}^{3}\subset\mathbb{R}^{4}:

𝒮3={𝐱∈ℝ4|∥𝐱∥=1}.superscript𝒮3conditional-set𝐱superscriptℝ4delimited-∥∥𝐱1\displaystyle\mathcal{S}^{3}=\{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}~{}~{}|~{}~{}\lVert\mathbf{x}\rVert=1\}. (44)

Of particular relevance for the work here, quaternions are a double-covering of all possible 3D rotations, i.e., there are two quaternions that correspond to every 3D rotation. More specifically, every pair of antipodal quaternions represent the same rotation, which can be seen mathematically in (43) by taking quaternion 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} with angle θ𝜃\theta, and replacing θ𝜃\theta with the equivalent angle θ+2​π𝜃2𝜋\theta+2\pi. Note that while we could reduce the set 𝒮3subscript𝒮3\mathcal{S}_{3} so that it is a 1-to-1 mapping, it would not change the results in this section.

Another version of quaternions we will consider are unconstrained quaternions, which are constructed by eliminating the unit-length constraint of quaternions, thereby allowing any vector in ℝ4superscriptℝ4\mathbb{R}^{4} to be associated with a 3D rotation after normalization into a unit quaternion. Unconstrained quaternions are advantageous as they allow a neural network to output any 4D vector as a valid parameterization of rotation. We will consider unconstrained quaternions in Section 5.5.

5.2 Rotational distance

We can derive the rotational distance between two quaternions using the equation for the rotational distance of exponential coordinates in Proposition 9, which is written as a function of axis 𝐞𝐞\mathbf{e} and angle θ𝜃\theta.

Proposition 14.

The rotational distance between quaternions 𝐪1,𝐪2∈𝒮3subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2superscript𝒮3\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3} is given by:

dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)=2​cos−1⁡(|𝐪1⋅𝐪2|).distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪22superscript1⋅subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=2\cos^{-1}(\lvert\mathbf{q}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{q}_{2}\rvert). (45)
{pf}

Using (43), we can write the quaternion vectors as

𝐪1=[cos⁡θ12𝐞1​sin⁡θ12],𝐪2=[cos⁡θ22𝐞2​sin⁡θ22].formulae-sequencesubscript𝐪1matrixsubscript𝜃12subscript𝐞1subscript𝜃12subscript𝐪2matrixsubscript𝜃22subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃22\displaystyle\mathbf{q}_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\\ \mathbf{e}_{1}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\end{bmatrix},~{}~{}~{}\mathbf{q}_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\\ \mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\end{bmatrix}. (46)

Taking the dot product of 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} yields

𝐪1⋅𝐪2=cos⁡θ12​cos⁡θ22+𝐞1⋅𝐞2​sin⁡θ12​sin⁡θ22.⋅subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2absentsubscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22⋅subscript𝐞1subscript𝐞2subscript𝜃12subscript𝜃22\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \mathbf{q}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{q}_{2}&=\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}+\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}.\end{aligned} (47)

The RHS of (47) is exactly the expression in the absolute value in (16), which is the equation for the rotational distance between axis-angle pairs (θ1subscript𝜃1\theta_{1},𝐞1subscript𝐞1\mathbf{e}_{1}) and (θ2subscript𝜃2\theta_{2},𝐞2subscript𝐞2\mathbf{e}_{2}). Since 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} correspond to the same 3D rotations as (θ1subscript𝜃1\theta_{1},𝐞1subscript𝐞1\mathbf{e}_{1}) and (θ2subscript𝜃2\theta_{2},𝐞2subscript𝐞2\mathbf{e}_{2}), respectively, plugging (47) into (16) yields (45). □□\square

We can also express the rotational distance between two quaternions as a function of the angle between their 4D quaternion vectors. This result will be used in Section 5.3.

Proposition 15.

Consider two quaternions 𝐪1,𝐪2∈𝒮3subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2superscript𝒮3\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3}, and let ϕitalic-ϕ\phi denote the angle between the 4D quaternion vectors. The rotational distance between the quaternions can be expressed in terms of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi as:

dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)={2​ϕ,ϕ∈[0,π/2]2​π−2​ϕ,ϕ∈[π/2,π].distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2cases2italic-ϕitalic-ϕ0𝜋22𝜋2italic-ϕitalic-ϕ𝜋2𝜋\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=\begin{cases}2\phi,&\phi\in[0,\pi/2]\\ 2\pi-2\phi,&\phi\in[\pi/2,\pi].\end{cases} (48)
{pf}

Applying the formula which relates the dot product and angle between two vectors, and noting that 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} are unit length, we have

cos⁡ϕ=𝐪1⋅𝐪2∥𝐪1∥​∥𝐪2∥=𝐪1⋅𝐪2.italic-ϕabsent⋅subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪1delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪2⋅subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \cos\phi&=\frac{\mathbf{q}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{q}_{2}}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}\rVert}=\mathbf{q}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{q}_{2}.\end{aligned} (49)

Plugging (49) into (45) yields

dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)=2​cos−1⁡(|cos⁡ϕ|).distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪22superscript1italic-ϕ\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=2\cos^{-1}(\lvert\cos\phi\rvert). (50)

Now note the following property

cos−1⁡(|cos⁡ϕ|)={ϕ,ϕ∈[0,π/2]π−ϕ,ϕ∈[π/2,π].superscript1italic-ϕcasesitalic-ϕitalic-ϕ0𝜋2𝜋italic-ϕitalic-ϕ𝜋2𝜋\cos^{-1}(\lvert\cos\phi\rvert)=\begin{cases}\phi,&\phi\in[0,\pi/2]\\ \pi-\phi,&\phi\in[\pi/2,\pi].\end{cases} (51)

Plugging (51) into (50) yields (48). □□\square

5.3 Planar analysis

To determine the distance ratio constant of quaternions, we need to optimize over all possible pairs of quaternions, where each pair consists of the eight degrees of freedom in 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2}, and the two constraints ∥𝐪1∥=1delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪11\lVert\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert=1 and ∥𝐪2∥=1delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪21\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}\rVert=1. The number of dimensions and constraints in this analysis is challenging, but we can analyze this problem in the plane defined by 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2}, which reduces the number of variables and simplifies the analysis.

Lemma 16.

Consider two quaternions 𝐪1,𝐪2∈𝒮3subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2superscript𝒮3\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3}, and let c𝑐c denote their Euclidean distance. The ratio of the rotational distance and the Euclidean distance between the two quaternions is given by:

dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)∥𝐪2−𝐪1∥={4​sin−1⁡(c2)/c,c∈(0,2](2​π−4​sin−1⁡(c2))/c,c∈[2,2].distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪2subscript𝐪1cases4superscript1𝑐2𝑐𝑐022𝜋4superscript1𝑐2𝑐𝑐22\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}=\begin{cases}4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})/c,&c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]\\ (2\pi-4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}))/c,&c\in[\sqrt{2},2].\end{cases} (52)
{pf}

We start by noting that any two quaternions define a plane, and hence we can analyze their relationship in that plane. A diagram is shown in Fig. 4. Since 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} lie on the unit circle, the distance between them can be interpreted as a chord length. Denoting this chord length as c𝑐c, we have

c=∥𝐪2−𝐪1∥.𝑐delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪2subscript𝐪1c=\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert. (53)

Let ϕitalic-ϕ\phi denote the angle between the 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} vector and the 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} vector. We can relate the chord length c𝑐c, angle ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, and radius ρ𝜌\rho using the trigonometric formula ϕ=2​sin−1⁡(c2​ρ)italic-ϕ2superscript1𝑐2𝜌\phi=2\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2\rho}). Since quaternions are unit-length, in this case ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1, and we can write the relationship between c𝑐c and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi as

ϕ=2​sin−1⁡(c2).italic-ϕ2superscript1𝑐2\displaystyle\phi=2\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}). (54)

Plugging (54) into (48), and converting the intervals accordingly, yields

dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)={4​sin−1⁡(c2),c∈(0,2]2​π−4​sin−1⁡(c2),c∈[2,2].distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2cases4superscript1𝑐2𝑐022𝜋4superscript1𝑐2𝑐22\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=\begin{cases}4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}),&c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]\\ 2\pi-4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}),&c\in[\sqrt{2},2].\end{cases} (55)

Plugging (55) and (53) into the LHS of (52) yields the RHS of (52). Note that in (52) we do not consider c=0𝑐0c=0 as it corresponds to 𝐪1=𝐪2subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{1}=\mathbf{q}_{2}, which is not considered in the distance ratio constant from Definition 6. □□\square

5.4 Distance ratio constant

Next, we will derive the distance ratio constant. To facilitate the analysis, we will use the planar interpretation from Section 5.3.

Theorem 17.

The distance ratio constant, μ𝜇\mu, of quaternions 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} is:

μ=sup𝐪1,𝐪2∈𝒮3𝐪1≠𝐪2dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)∥𝐪2−𝐪1∥=π2.𝜇subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2superscript𝒮3subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪2subscript𝐪1𝜋2\displaystyle\mu=\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3}\\ \mathbf{q}_{1}\neq\mathbf{q}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{2}}. (56)
{pf}

In Lemma 16 we showed that we can write the sensitivity of any two quaternions in terms of the single variable c𝑐c, which represents their Euclidean distance and chord length in the plane defined by the two quaternion vectors. Taking the derivative of (52) with respect to c𝑐c yields

dd​c​dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)∥𝐪2−𝐪1∥={4c2​(c4−c2−sin−1⁡(c2)),c∈(0,2]−4c2​(c4−c2+cos−1⁡(c2)),c∈[2,2].𝑑𝑑𝑐distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪2subscript𝐪1cases4superscript𝑐2𝑐4superscript𝑐2superscript1𝑐2𝑐024superscript𝑐2𝑐4superscript𝑐2superscript1𝑐2𝑐22\displaystyle\frac{d}{dc}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}{=}\begin{cases}\frac{4}{c^{2}}\left(\frac{c}{\sqrt{4-c^{2}}}-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\right),&c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]\\ \frac{-4}{c^{2}}\left(\frac{c}{\sqrt{4-c^{2}}}+\cos^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\right),&c\in[\sqrt{2},2].\end{cases} (57)

To begin, consider the first case of (57), where c∈(0,2]𝑐02c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]. The second term can be rearranged as follows:

c4−c2−sin−1⁡(c2)=(c2)/(1−(c2))2−sin−1⁡(c2)=tan⁡(sin−1⁡(c2))−sin−1⁡(c2)𝑐4superscript𝑐2superscript1𝑐2absent𝑐2superscript1𝑐22superscript1𝑐2missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript1𝑐2superscript1𝑐2\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \frac{c}{\sqrt{4-c^{2}}}-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})&=(\tfrac{c}{2})/\sqrt{(1-(\tfrac{c}{2}))^{2}}-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\\ &=\tan(\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}))-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\end{aligned} (58)

where in the last step we used the identity tan⁡(sin−1⁡x)=x/1−x2superscript1𝑥𝑥1superscript𝑥2\tan(\sin^{-1}x)=x/\sqrt{1-x^{2}}. Note that c/2𝑐2c/2 is positive, so sin−1⁡(c2)superscript1𝑐2\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}) is on the interval (0,π/2]0𝜋2(0,\pi/2]. Because tan⁡x>x𝑥𝑥\tan x>x for x∈(0,π/2]𝑥0𝜋2x\in(0,\pi/2], the bottom equation in (58) is positive, which since c>0𝑐0c>0, implies that (57) is positive in the case of c∈(0,2]𝑐02c\in(0,\sqrt{2}].

Next, consider the second case of (57), where c∈[2,2]𝑐22c\in[\sqrt{2},2]. Restricting the interval to [2,2)22[\sqrt{2},2), the second term consists of the sum of two non-negative terms, which is non-negative. Since −4/c24superscript𝑐2-4/c^{2} is negative, (57) is non-positive in the case of c∈[2,2)𝑐22c\in[\sqrt{2},2).

In summary, the derivative of (52) with respect to c𝑐c is positive for c∈(0,2]𝑐02c\in(0,\sqrt{2}] and non-positive for c∈[2,2)𝑐22c\in[\sqrt{2},2), so (52) is maximized at c=2𝑐2c=\sqrt{2} on the interval c∈(0,2)𝑐02c\in(0,2). Evaluating (52) with c=2𝑐2c=\sqrt{2} yields π/2𝜋2\pi/\sqrt{2}. As (52) equals zero when c=2𝑐2c=2, it has a maximum value of π/2𝜋2\pi/\sqrt{2} on the interval (0,2]02(0,2]. □□\square

5.5 Unconstrained quaternions

We now consider unconstrained quaternions, which as we mentioned in Section 5.1, are constructed by eliminating the unit-length constraint of quaternions, thereby allowing any vector in ℝ4superscriptℝ4\mathbb{R}^{4} to be associated with a 3D rotation after normalization into a unit quaternion. We now derive the distance ratio constant of unconstrained quaternions.

Theorem 18.

The distance ratio constant, μ𝜇\mu, of unconstrained quaternions 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2} is:

μ=sup𝐪1,𝐪2∈ℝ4𝐪1≠𝐪2dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)∥𝐪2−𝐪1∥=∞.𝜇subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2superscriptℝ4subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐪2subscript𝐪1\displaystyle\mu=\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}\\ \mathbf{q}_{1}\neq\mathbf{q}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}=\infty. (59)
{pf}

Consider any two unconstrained quaternions 𝐪1,𝐪2∈ℝ4subscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2superscriptℝ4\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{4} which do not correspond to the same rotation. Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 denote their rotational distance. Now consider the scalar, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and scalar multiples of 𝐪1subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q}_{1} and 𝐪2subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q}_{2}: ϵ​𝐪1italic-ϵsubscript𝐪1\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{1} and ϵ​𝐪2italic-ϵsubscript𝐪2\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{2}. Since scaling an unconstrained quaternion does not change its associated rotation, we have

α=dist​(𝐪1,𝐪2)=dist​(ϵ​𝐪1,ϵ​𝐪2)>0.𝛼distsubscript𝐪1subscript𝐪2distitalic-ϵsubscript𝐪1italic-ϵsubscript𝐪20\displaystyle\alpha=\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=\mathrm{dist}(\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{1},\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{2})>0. (60)

Taking the limit as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon goes to zero, we have

limϵ→0dist​(ϵ​𝐪1,ϵ​𝐪2)∥ϵ​𝐪2−ϵ​𝐪1∥=α0=∞.subscript→italic-ϵ0distitalic-ϵsubscript𝐪1italic-ϵsubscript𝐪2delimited-∥∥italic-ϵsubscript𝐪2italic-ϵsubscript𝐪1𝛼0\displaystyle\lim_{\epsilon\rightarrow 0}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{1},\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{2}-\epsilon\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}=\frac{\alpha}{0}=\infty. (61)

□□\square

Mapping an unconstrained quaternion to a unit quaternion is performed using a unit-normalization function. We now calculate the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of a unit-normalization function.

Proposition 19.

Let 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} denote the unit-normalization function. The Euclidean Lipschitz constant of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is ∞\infty:

sup𝐱1≠𝐱2∥𝐟​(𝐱2)−𝐟​(𝐱1)∥∥𝐱2−𝐱1∥=∞.subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2delimited-∥∥𝐟subscript𝐱2𝐟subscript𝐱1delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱2subscript𝐱1\sup_{\mathbf{x}_{1}\neq\mathbf{x}_{2}}\frac{\lVert\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2})-\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1})\rVert}{\lVert\mathbf{x}_{2}-\mathbf{x}_{1}\rVert}=\infty. (62)
{pf}

To prove this proposition, we can show that the fraction in (62) approaches infinity for some vectors 𝐱1subscript𝐱1\mathbf{x}_{1} and 𝐱2subscript𝐱2\mathbf{x}_{2}. Consider two unit vectors 𝐮1≠𝐮2subscript𝐮1subscript𝐮2\mathbf{u}_{1}\neq\mathbf{u}_{2}. Let ϵ​𝐮1italic-ϵsubscript𝐮1\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{1} and ϵ​𝐮2italic-ϵsubscript𝐮2\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{2} denote scalings of these vectors by ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0. Since 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is a normalization function, we have 𝐟​(ϵ​𝐮1)=𝐮1𝐟italic-ϵsubscript𝐮1subscript𝐮1\mathbf{f}(\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{1})=\mathbf{u}_{1} and 𝐟​(ϵ​𝐮2)=𝐮2𝐟italic-ϵsubscript𝐮2subscript𝐮2\mathbf{f}(\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{2})=\mathbf{u}_{2}. Let b𝑏b denote the Euclidean distance between 𝐟​(𝐱1)𝐟subscript𝐱1\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1}) and 𝐟​(𝐱2)𝐟subscript𝐱2\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2}):

b=∥𝐟​(ϵ​𝐮2)−𝐟​(ϵ​𝐮1)∥=∥𝐮2−𝐮1∥>0.𝑏delimited-∥∥𝐟italic-ϵsubscript𝐮2𝐟italic-ϵsubscript𝐮1delimited-∥∥subscript𝐮2subscript𝐮10\displaystyle b=\lVert\mathbf{f}(\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{2})-\mathbf{f}(\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{1})\rVert=\lVert\mathbf{u}_{2}-\mathbf{u}_{1}\rVert>0. (63)

The fraction in (62) for vectors ϵ​𝐮1italic-ϵsubscript𝐮1\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{1} and ϵ​𝐮2italic-ϵsubscript𝐮2\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{2} as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon approaches 0 is

limϵ→0∥𝐟​(ϵ​𝐮2)−𝐟​(ϵ​𝐮1)∥∥ϵ​𝐮2−ϵ​𝐮1∥=b0=∞.subscript→italic-ϵ0delimited-∥∥𝐟italic-ϵsubscript𝐮2𝐟italic-ϵsubscript𝐮1delimited-∥∥italic-ϵsubscript𝐮2italic-ϵsubscript𝐮1𝑏0\lim_{\epsilon\rightarrow 0}\frac{\lVert\mathbf{f}(\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{2})-\mathbf{f}(\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{1})\rVert}{\lVert\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{2}-\epsilon\mathbf{u}_{1}\rVert}=\frac{b}{0}=\infty. (64)

□□\square

6 Construction of a pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds

In the previous two sections, we derived the distance ratio constant for several rotation parameterizations. In this section, we will consider the task of using these results along with Theorem 7 to design a pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds. We will show that unconstrained exponential coordinates are the only rotation parameterization we have considered which can accomplish this task. We will then design and train a pose estimation network using unconstrained exponential coordinates, and compute sensitivity bounds for it.

6.1 Summary of rotation parameterizations

In summary, we have derived the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates and quaternions, as well as unconstrained versions of both of these parameterizations. The results are summarized in Fig. 5.

We also verified these results to be accurate by randomly sampling 107superscript10710^{7} pairs of 3D rotations and calculating the argument of the distance ratio constant for each pair.

We now consider the task of constructing a pose estimation network using each of these parameterizations, and calculating the rotational Lipschitz constant for each network. Unfortunately, this task is unrealizable for most of these parameterizations. Using exponential coordinates would require that the neural network only output vectors with magnitude less than or equal to π𝜋\pi, which is not straightforward to accomplish. Similarly, using quaternions would require the neural network to only output vectors with unit magnitude. This unit magnitude constraint could be enforced using a unit-normalization function, but as we showed in Proposition 19, the unit-normalization function has an infinite Lipschitz constant. Similarly, unconstrained quaternions have an unbounded distance ratio constant.

However, unconstrained exponential coordinates do not have any of these challenges as they associate any vector in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3} with a valid 3D rotation, and they have a bounded distance ratio constant. As a result, it is possible to build a pose estimation neural network which outputs rotation in the form of an unconstrained three-dimensional vector, and then determine a bound on the network’s rotational Lipschitz constant using Theorem 7.

6.2 A pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds

In this section, we will design and train a neural network which outputs rotation in the form of unconstrained exponential coordinates, and then calculate a bound on its rotational Lipschitz constant. Our network outputs six-dimensional vectors, in which the first three states represent position and the last three states represent unconstrained exponential coordinates.

We constructed a feedforward network with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation functions, which has a similar architecture to the original AlexNet [20]. The network architecture is shown in Fig. 6.

We consider our object of interest to be the “soup can” object from the YCB data set. We generated each image in the training and test data by generating renderings of the soup can at random poses using the computer graphics program Blender, and then superimposing the rendering on a random background image. Our training data consisted of 200,000 renderings superimposed on random background images from the SUN397 dataset. Our test data consisted of 10,000 renderings superimposed on background images from the 2017 COCO dataset. Each image was of size 3×256×25632562563{\times}256{\times}256, and sample images are shown in Fig. 7.

We created the cost function for the network as follows. Let 𝐳i∈ℝ3subscript𝐳𝑖superscriptℝ3\mathbf{z}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} and 𝐳^i∈ℝ3subscript^𝐳𝑖superscriptℝ3\hat{\mathbf{z}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} denote the true and estimated position for the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} data point, respectively. Let 𝐬i∈ℬπsubscript𝐬𝑖subscriptℬ𝜋\mathbf{s}_{i}\in\mathcal{B}_{\pi} denote the true exponential coordinates, and 𝐬^i∈ℝ3subscript^𝐬𝑖superscriptℝ3\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} denote the estimated unconstrained coordinates for the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} data point. Letting m𝑚m denote the number of data points, we used the following cost function:

cost=∑i=1m∥𝐳i−𝐳^i∥2+dist​(𝐬i,𝐬^i)costsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐳𝑖subscript^𝐳𝑖2distsubscript𝐬𝑖subscript^𝐬𝑖\textrm{cost}=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lVert\mathbf{z}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{z}}_{i}\rVert^{2}+\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{i},\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{i}) (65)

where dist​(⋅,⋅)dist⋅⋅\mathrm{dist}(\cdot,\cdot) is the rotational distance equation from (16).

We trained the network using the Adadelta optimization algorithm with an initial learning rate of 10−1superscript10110^{-1}, and reduced the learning rate to 10−2superscript10210^{-2} when the error plateaued. We trained the network for 235 epochs, which resulted in average test sample rotation and position errors of 13°°\degree and 7cm, respectively. Note that about 1% of the network’s exponential coordinate estimates had a norm larger than π𝜋\pi (i.e., were outside of the set ℬπsubscriptℬ𝜋\mathcal{B}_{\pi}) for both training and test data.

The network outputs a six-dimensional vector which represents position and exponential coordinates. In order to analyze the position and rotation portions of the network independently, we split the network into two sub-networks by splitting the final fully-connected layer into two parts. We determined upper bounds on the Euclidean Lipschitz constants of the position and rotation sub-networks to be 13×10913superscript10913\times 10^{9} and 84×10984superscript10984\times 10^{9}, respectively. Using the latter value along with Theorems 7 and 12, we determined the following upper bound on the rotational Lipschitz constant of the network:

Lr≤84×109.subscript𝐿𝑟84superscript109\displaystyle L_{r}\leq 84\times 10^{9}. (66)

Note that all of our computed Lipschitz bounds are very large, but are of similar magnitude to classification networks with comparable architectures.

Finally, we can use Corollary 8 to determine a bound on the rotational change of the output, given a bound on input perturbations. Using (12), we can determine that if the Euclidean distance of two inputs is less than or equal to ϵ=1.1×10−11italic-ϵ1.1superscript1011\epsilon=1.1\times 10^{-11}, then the rotational distance between the outputs will be less than or equal to 1 radian. We could also determine this bound for different values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we approached the task of deriving sensitivity bounds for pose estimation neural networks. We created a sensitivity measure that is a type of Lipschitz constant which measures the maximum rotational distance between two outputs of a network with respect to the Euclidean distance between the corresponding inputs. We then showed how a bound on this measure can be calculated from the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of the network and the distance ratio constant of the rotation parameterization. We derived the distance ratio constant for various rotation parameterizations, and discussed why most of these parameterizations, except for unconstrained exponential coordinates, make it difficult to compute a network-wide bound. We then constructed a neural network which outputs pose as a concatenation of position and unconstrained exponential coordinates, and calculated a bound on the rotational Lipschitz constant of the network.

There are several useful directions of future work we can consider. One is to further analyze 2D projection parameterizations. These parameterizations have shown to be very effective when used in pose estimation neural networks, and are also versatile due to the fact that these networks can be applied to images with a variety of camera intrinsics.

Finally, we again note that our sensitivity bounds were very large, but are of comparable magnitude to sensitivity bounds for classification networks. The high sensitivity of these bounds is a direct result of the bound on the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of the network being large. Therefore, in order to decrease our bounds and make them more practical, it is important to develop a way to calculate tighter bounds on the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of a network, or to constrain the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of the network during training. Note that both of these topics are actively being researched and have wide-ranging applicability in the field of deep learning.
